@junichi11 Thanks, will merge it once CI finishes.

Good day mbien. **My posted issue is wrong**! I uninstalled every JDK, cleaned the Windows system variables, deleted GF, reinstalled JDK 17.0.6, GF 7.0.3, NB 17. **The problem doesn't exist**, it was the fault of my machine configuration. Forgive me for wasting your time. > squash the commits and force push updates to your PR branch

Can do, though I generally dislike doing that as it makes it harder to track history and manage reviews. Out of curiosity, is this some policy for the repo, and if so, why? Squash-merging the PR would result in a single trunk commit anyway, the purported justification: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=74681408#SubmittingPullRequests-SquashingcommitsonaPullRequest
See eg. #5617 Squash-merging through the GitHub UI often has issues, and squash-merging locally and pushing to master loses the link with the PR (which we need).  No perfect answer! :smile:

there is also no requirement to have a PR produce a single commit. Sometimes it is better to separate things which don't belong together in one commit. So you force push into the branch to produce the cleaned up history, then you merge as is.

I personally find it rarely useful to go through the commit history in PRs (unless it has been cleaned up). Commits like "implemented review requests" have mostly only temporary value to communicate with other reviewers while the review is going on. Once its is reviewed, all what counts are the resulting commits (or single commit as in this case).

also as last step before merge I look at this:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans/pull/5739.patch

if the commit headers, emails co-authors etc are all correct I merge, without any github magic in between which might lead to surprises.

> Aside : Would be great if it was possible to link images directly in the FlatLaf properties file loading, although I guess that would add some complications, particularly as we'd want to specify the class (ImageUtilities) that loads them. 

That could be solved by specifying an "icon loader". E.g.:

~~~java
FlatLaf.iconLoader = org.openide.util.ImageUtilities.loadImage()
Tree.closedIcon = org/netbeans/swing/plaf/resources/hidpi-folder-closed.png
~~~

Then FlatLaf could detect whether the icon is specified as a path and use the icon loader to load it.

> Maybe an option to include a second String argument (eg. path) on the line to pass into the icon constructor?

Also a good idea.

I'll implement those ideas in one of the next FlatLaf versions. Thx

@matthiasblaesing problem fixed

Ok, I think this is a bug in the installer. I created a version without the pack200. Only to see that it fails too.

I think this happens because:
https://github.com/apache/netbeans-native-installers/blob/5cb81a27c543c92b1150c7c277d9cfd9d615e6b0/src/main/cpp/launcher/windows/src/JavaUtils.c#L638

Checks that does the pack200 exist. If not, everything fails.

I think it should perhaps not fail there immediately. I think it should fail in the `unpackJars` method IF it manages to find something to unpack to begin with.

I was able to get this work for us by adding a fake `unpack200.exe` (0 bytes) to our bundled JDK 17. This then bypasses the check and as we don't have anything to unpack.... we are off the hook.

So yeah, I think this is a bug in NBI. Given pack200 was already removed in JDK 14... I think it is not fair to assume pack200 is there anymore.

Amazing. @tonihele THANK YOU for posting this. I ran into the exact same issue today, exactly 9 hours after you posted the fix! Creating a 0-byte `unpack200.exe` in the bundled JDK bin/ folder worked like a charm. Very fortunate timing... you've saved me countless hours of infuriating debugging.

@neilcsmith-net, or other NB folks, if you're listening - it is awfully silly for the installer to fail on a missing `unpack200.exe`, in cases where pack200 compression is disabled (so that `unpack200.exe` isn't actually necessary to complete the installation!)

More generally, there are evidently a number of us who rely on NBI to distribute our applications. It would be helpful to receive some official guidance from the NB team on the future of NBI. I've been using NetBeans since version 7, and I don't think the NBI code has changed much since then, if at all - despite being rife with typos and bugs. Is the use of installers still an officially supported workflow? Or is it effectively deprecated? If the latter, some documentation clarifying the supported alternatives, and detailing a suggested migration path, would be very welcome.

[Don't take this as criticism - NB is awesome! - more a desire for clarification, so that I can make informed decisions about the future architecture of my application.]

Did you bring over settings and plugins when upgrading the IDE?  One potential cause for scanning issues is an older version of nb-javac from plugins than is now bundled in the IDE.  Using a clean run (new userdir and cachedir) of the IDE is a good idea in such cases to verify concerns caused in importing settings / plugins, particularly from a few releases back.  Cleaning out the cachedir by itself can occasionally fix issues - something I used to notice particularly on first runs when nb-javac was a plugin.

I would use JDK 11, 17 or 19, as they were the main tested on JDKs for NB17 - it's unlikely but possible JDK 12 was a cause of issue.

Closing this as you said you've resolved the issue.  Comment again if the problem recurs with the current setup.

## Steps to reproduce:

* On a linux system, create a new empty file (the file type is irrelevant, it is not just for PHP). Let's name it `test.md`.
* Activate *View -> Show Non-printable Characters*
* Type `TEST` and Save
* optional: Add the new file to the Git index with `git add test.md`


## Actual result without Return

Compare the screenshots of Netbeans (left) and the output of `cat -e test.md` in a linux terminal:

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1118790/231089294-2e47e14d-a6ad-4957-ba97-24f196fa32bd.png)

In the Netbeans editor it shows the  at the end of the line. But when you print the file at the terminal you see, that there is no trailing LF character at the end of the line. 

Running `git diff --cached test.md` will output:

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1118790/231096981-ac59cd48-8693-4763-96ac-c694ac08b0f3.png)

This indicates that Git is missing the LF at the end of the file.


## Actual result with Return

Now, press *Return*, save and compare the screenshots again:

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1118790/231090832-c5c10f20-945d-45c1-9772-d32e0dbbe8ac.png)

Netbeans shows two lines now, although other linux tools interprete this as one line.

If you run `git add test.md` and `git diff --cached test.md` again, Git will also show only one line **without the "No newline at end of file" notice**.


## Expected result

For files with Unix (LF) line terminators, I expect that **every** line is terminated with a LF character:

![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1118790/231102645-095d7f64-3e8f-44de-b2b5-5adabdbfcdea.png)

I hope this helps to understand the issue.

> How does this setting interact with other ways of manipulating FlatLAF properties, such as the "Edit custom properties" button, or changing platform/o.n.swing.laf.flatlaf/src/org/netbeans/swing/laf/flatlaf/FlatLightLaf.properties/FlatDarkLaf.properties?

The accent color is stored in NB preferences store and overrides `@accentColor`.
Function `systemColor(accent)` is used in properties files to get this color into FlatLaf UI defaults.
See PR https://github.com/JFormDesigner/FlatLaf/pull/607

Yes.
